message_1:
In the game of Nim, there are two players who take turns removing objects from a pile. Each player can take any number of objects from the pile, but they must take at least one object. The player who takes the last object wins. 

Suppose there are 15 objects in the initial pile. If Player 1 goes first and both players play optimally, how many objects will Player 1 need to take in their first turn to guarantee a win?
message_2:
To guarantee a win in the game of Nim, a player must force their opponent into a losing position. In this case, we want to find a number of objects that Player 1 can take, such that the remaining pile size is a multiple of 4 (since both players can take up to 3 objects per turn). This will force Player 2 into a losing position, as no matter how many objects they take, Player 1 can always take enough objects to maintain a multiple of 4 in the pile.

15 is not a multiple of 4, but the closest multiple of 4 is 12. Therefore, Player 1 should take 3 objects in their first turn, leaving 12 objects in the pile. This will force Player 2 into a losing position, and Player 1 can guarantee a win by playing optimally.
